title: Environmentally relevant concentrations of boscalid exposure affects the neurobehavioral response of zebrafish by disrupting visual and nervous systems

affiliation.laboratory: Risk Assessment Laboratory for Bee Products Quality and Safety of Ministry of Agriculture

authors.last: T I C L E I N F O

abstract: Boscalid is a persistent fungicide that is frequently detected in surface waters and may be neurotoxic to aquatic organisms. Herein, we evaluated the effects of environmentally relevant boscalid concentrations to zebrafish to explore its potentially neurotoxic mechanisms of effect. Behavioral responses (swimming, phototaxis, and predation), histopathology, transcriptomics, biochemical parameter analysis and gene expression of larval and adult zebrafish following boscalid treatment were assessed. We found that boscalid significantly inhibited the locomotor ability and phototactic response of larvae after an 8-d exposure, and altered the locomotor activity, predation trajectories and ability in adults after a 21-d exposure. It was noted that predation rates of zebrafish were significantly decreased by 30% and 100% after exposure to 0.1 and 1.0 mg/L boscalid, respectively. Adverse alterations in the cell differentiation of eyes and brain injury were also observed in both larvae and adults following boscalid exposure. The expression of genes related to neurodevelopment, neurotransmission, eye development, and visual function, in conjunction with RNA-Seq results, indicated that boscalid may impair visual phototransduction and nervous system processes in larval zebrafish. Conclusively, boscalid exposure may affect the neurobehavioral response of zebrafish by impairing proper visual and nervous system function.

abstract.text: Boscalid is a persistent fungicide that is frequently detected in surface waters and may be neurotoxic to aquatic organisms. Herein, we evaluated the effects of environmentally relevant boscalid concentrations to zebrafish to explore its potentially neurotoxic mechanisms of effect. It was noted that predation rates of zebrafish were significantly decreased by 30% and 100% after exposure to 0.1 and 1.0 mg/L boscalid, respectively. Adverse alterations in the cell differentiation of eyes and brain injury were also observed in both larvae and adults following boscalid exposure. The expression of genes related to neurodevelopment, neurotransmission, eye development, and visual function, in conjunction with RNA-Seq results, indicated that boscalid may impair visual phototransduction and nervous system processes in larval zebrafish. Conclusively, boscalid exposure may affect the neurobehavioral response of zebrafish by impairing proper visual and nervous system function.

body_text.text: Succinate dehydrogenase inhibitors (SDHIs) are the fastest growing fungicides on the market (He et al., 2018) . Boscalid is among the most widely used SDHIs, where it acts as a broad-spectrum fungicide on a variety of cash crops. Due to the slow degradation of boscalid in soil and aquatic systems, it has been frequently detected in sediment, water samples and even aquatic organisms collected in the environment (Houbraken et al., 2017; Deknock et al., 2019) . Boscalid was frequently detected in bed sediments, fish, and sand crab tissue samples from the Santa Maria estuary in California (Smalling et al., 2013) . Boscalid was also detected in 50% of water samples collected from the Rhineland-Palatinate rivers (Germany), and even exceeded the threshold value for drinking water for pesticides of 0.100 µg/L in two samples (Karlsson et al., 2016) . Concentrations of boscalid measured in the Hove catchment streams (Denmark) was up to 0.027 µg/L (Rasmussen et al., 2013) and 1.371 µg/L in fishponds of the Lorraine Region (France) (Gaillard et al., 2016) . Additionally, up to 36 μg/L of boscalid were detected in coastal watersheds in California, USA (Smalling and Orlando, 2011) , exceeding concentrations shown to impair growth, energy reserves, reproduction, and survival in Allorchestes compressa (Vu et al., 2016) .

Previous studies have shown that environmental stressors, such as environmental pollutants (including fluoxetine, atrazine, and metolachlor), affect fish behavior and even survival (Egan et al., 2009; Jacquin et al., 2020) . Fish behavioral testing has demonstrated to be an effective means of assessing the neurotoxicity of environmental pollutants (Claudio et al., 2000) . The use of zebrafish (Danio rerio) for neurobiological behavioral testing has shown great promise, particularly those involved in motor and visually-mediated behavioral tests (Bilotta, 2000; Brockerhoff, 2006) . Motor behaviors occur sequentially during the development of zebrafish (Wang et al., 2013 , which includes early spontaneous tail curling, escape responses to touch and free swimming. Common visual behaviors, such as the visual startle response, phototaxis, and the optomotor and optokinetic responses have been extensively studied in zebrafish (Li, 2001; Mueller and Neuhauss, 2010 ). The visual system extracts optical information from the environment to guide common behaviors in fish, including predatory responses, socializing and breeding (Haug et al., 2010; Chen and Fernald, 2011) . Previous studies have shown that eye movement is enhanced during feeding, indicating that visual input is important for catching prey (Rice and Westneat, 2005) . Stephenson et al. (2012) found that fishes' response to reliable information regarding predation risk in the environment depends on a combination of chemical and visual cues (Stephenson et al., 2012) .

Previous studies have shown that SDHIs, such as thifluzamide and penthiopyrad, significantly decreased the frequency of tail coiling in zebrafish embryos and reduced the free swimming and locomotor activity in larvae following exposure (Yang et al., 2016; Qian et al., 2019a) . Similarly, boscalid significantly decreased the spontaneous tail coiling frequency in zebrafish embryos, and further decreased the movement and altered tendency of locomotion in larvae following exposure to 5 mg/L (Wang et al., 2020) . These studies indicated that SDHIs can impair proper motor behavior in zebrafish under high exposure concentrations, however, no research has been reported on the effects of SDHIs on visual behavior in zebrafish following exposure to environmentally relevant concentrations.

For this study, embryonic and adult zebrafish were used as representative model organisms to investigate the effects of boscalid on motor and visually-mediated behavioral responses and the underlying, potentially toxic mechanisms following exposure. The locomotor activity and phototactic response of larvae following sublethal exposures to boscalid, as well as the locomotor activity, predatory response and associated trajectories of adults following chronic exposure to environmentally relevant concentrations of boscalid were assessed. Histopathological and transcriptomic techniques were applied to further characterize the potential neurotoxic effects of boscalid to zebrafish. Additionally, acetylcholinesterase (AChE) activity, acetylcholine (ACh) concentrations, and the transcriptional regulation of proteins associated with neurodevelopment, neurotransmission, eye development, and visual function were assessed.

Boscalid (99.5% purity, analytical standard) was purchased from Dr. Ehrenstorfer GmbH (Germany). Boscalid (purity 98%) was purchased from Beijing Huarong Biological Hormone Plant (Beijing, China). A stock solution of 100,000 mg/L boscalid was prepared in analyticalgrade acetone and subsequently diluted to appropriate concentrations for each test. Reconstituted water and aerated natural water was used for embryo-larvae and adult tests, respectively, and were prepared as previously described (Mu et al., 2013; Qian et al., 2019b) . All reagents utilized in the present study were analytical grade.

Adult AB-strain zebrafish (four-months-old) were purchased from Beijing Hongda Gaofeng Aquarium Department. Zebrafish husbandry and embryo collection were carried out following the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) guidelines and as conducted previously (OECD, 2013; Zhu et al., 2015) . Similarly, the cultivation of D. magna in our laboratory followed OECD guidelines (OECD, 2004) . The subsequent tests were conducted after receiving the approval for research ethics from China Agricultural University.

Embryonic exposures were performed based on the methods outlined by the OECD guidelines and our previous studies (OECD, 1998; Qian et al., 2019a) . Two-hundred healthy embryos (approximately 2 h post-fertilization) per replicate were separately placed into glass beakers containing 200 mL of 0 (control), 0.3, 0.6, and 1.2 mg/L boscalid solutions (all groups, 0.01% acetone, v/v). After 4 d of exposure (dpe), ten larvae per replicate were placed into 24-well plates and cultured with the same exposure solution as before until the eighth day, when swimming behavior assays were conducted. Fifty larvae per beaker were pooled for the measurement of AChE activity and ACh concentration, with an additional forty larvae collected for RNA extraction and qPCR at 4 and 8 dpe.

Two separate trials, following the same exposure method previously described above, were conducted. The exposure concentrations were 0, 0.3, 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L. Twenty-four larvae per replicate were transferred into 96-well plates at 4 dpe and cultured until the eighth day, when a dark photokinetic assay was conducted. An additional twenty larvae per replicate were placed into a non-transparent black acrylic box at 5 and 8 dpe for the phototaxis response assay.

Sixty healthy embryos were placed into glass beakers filled with 60 mL of 0 and 1.2 mg/L boscalid solutions for a subsequent exposure. Fifty, 4 dpe larvae were pooled for RNA sequencing and five larvae were collected for histopathological observation at both 4 and 8 dpe.

Dead embryos were immediately removed from the beakers once identified. Each group was run in triplicate for all endpoints assessed (n = 3). During all exposure experiments, exposure solutions were prepared with reconstituted water and completely replaced daily. All samples collected for biochemical analysis were flash frozen in liquid nitrogen, and kept at − 80 • C.

A 21-d exposure experiment for adult zebrafish was conducted according to the methods described in the OECD guidelines and our previous studies (OECD, 2012; Qian et al., 2019b) . Following a one-month acclimation period, zebrafish (five-months-old) were placed into 4 L beakers containing a series of concentrations of boscalid solutions (0, 0.01, 0.1, and 1.0 mg/L). The test concentrations used (0.01 and 0.1 mg/L) were based on previously measured concentrations of boscalid in surface waters (ranging from 0.027 to 36 µg/L) (Reilly et al., 2012; Esteve-Turrillas et al., 2016; Papadakis et al., 2018) . A sublethal effect concentration of 1.0 mg/L was used, as according to our prior studies (Qian et al., 2019b) . Each replicate contained five adult zebrafish (n = 3). During exposures, zebrafish were fed dried brine shrimp, following the methods previous conducted (Chai et al., 2016) , and were fasted for 24 h before the end of exposure. All zebrafish were used for swimming and predatory behavioral assays. Afterwards, five zebrafish per replicate were anaesthetized in 0.03% MS-222, imaged and collected for histopathological examination. Each group was run in triplicate for all endpoints assessed (n = 3). During all exposure experiments, exposure solutions were prepared with reconstituted water and completely replaced daily.
All behavior tests were conducted after 10 min of acclimation of fish (larvae and adults).

For larvae, the swimming behavior assay was adopted from previously described methods (Hansen and Roslev, 2016; Qian et al., 2019a) . The assay was conducted under a 15-min continuous light. The swimming behavior of larvae at 5, 6, 7 and 8 dpe was recorded using a video camera with a sensor (Imaging Development Systems GmbH, Germany). Tracking videos were analyzed using LoliTrack software (Version 4.2.0; Loligo Systems, United States), which converted the tracking videos into bin files, and were then analyzed to assess several indicators of locomotion including average velocity, acceleration, distance moved, and activity time.

A dark photokinesis assay was performed in 8 dpe larvae following previously reported methods (Huang et al., 2015; Cao et al., 2019) . A 96-well plate was placed into the observation chamber of a DanioVision Tracking System (Noldus Information Technology, United States) with an infrared analog camera (25 frames/second). Behavioral responses of larvae were tracked under alternating cycles of dark (10 min) and light (10 min). The total test time was 50 min, and the start time was in the dark period. Tracking videos were analyzed using EthoVision software v10 (Noldus Information Technology, United States) to assess total distance moved.

A phototactic behavioral assay was conducted in 5 and 8 dpe larvae as previously described (Brockerhoff et al., 1995) . A 10.5 × 3 × 4 cm (L × W × H) acrylic box with a sliding partition separating two chambers (A and B) were prepared (Shi et al., 2019) . Chamber A was set as dark zone and chamber B was set as light zone (100 lux). Twenty larvae were placed into chamber A, and then the partition was removed when the test started. The partition was re-inserted into the box after 1 min. The number of larvae that moved from chamber A to B was recorded to calculate the percentage of migration.

For adult zebrafish, the swimming and predatory behavioral assays were preformed after 21-d of exposure. Adults were individually placed in a beaker containing 600 mL of natural water for swimming behavior assays. The detection method and data analysis were similar to that of larvae, though the total test time was 4 min. Subsequently, predatory behavioral assays, adapted and simplified based on previous studies, were carried out (Stephenson et al., 2012; Yu et al., 2013) . Three D. magna (one-month-old) were simultaneously placed into a beaker, and the predatory behavior of zebrafish was recorded for a 240 s duration. EthoVision XT 9 (Noldus Information Technology, United States) was used to obtain predation trajectories of adult zebrafish.

Total RNA extraction, library construction, clustering, and sequencing are described in detail in the Supplementary Material (text). Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis was applied in the description of gene functions of differentially expressed genes (DEGs) and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) (http://www.genome.jp/ kegg/) was used to analyze complex biological functions. To further verify RNA-Seq results, 14 representative DEGs were selected to undergo RT-qPCR with the same RNAs used in the construction of the RNA-Seq library. Primers sequences are provided in Table S1 .

Adult zebrafish were imaged following a 21-d exposure and the mean diameters of the eye and cornea were measured and analyzed using Image Pro-Plus 6.0 software (Media Cybernetics, Silver Spring, USA).

Both larval and adult fish were fixed in 10% formalin for 48 h, dehydrated in graded ethanol and xylene, and embedded in paraffin (Cao et al., 2016; Gratiana Eka et al., 2017) . All samples were sectioned at 4 µm using a refrigerated microtome (ERMA INC., Japan) and stained with hematoxylin and eosin (HE). Longitudinal sections of the eye and brain in larval fish were selected for analysis. Cross sections of brain and longitudinal sections of the eye, following decalcification, were taken in adults . The sections were examined using light microscopy (Olympus, Japan).

Retinal layers were distinguished in zebrafish as previously demonstrated (Vihtelic et al., 2005; Eastman and Lannoo, 2011) , with the predominately defined layers comprised of the retinal pigmented epithelium (RPE), photoreceptor layer (PL), outer nuclear layer (ONL), inner nuclear layer (INL), inner plexiform layer (IPL), ganglion cell layer (GCL) and lens as shown in Fig. 4B . The area of the round cell nucleus in the brain of larval zebrafish, and the thickness of the PL in the retina, as well as the density of the cerebellar granule cells (GrCs) in adults, was calculated using Image Pro-Plus 6.0 software.

All larval samples were homogenized with saline on ice and were then centrifuged (2500 rpm, 4 • C) for 10 min to obtain supernatants used for corresponding biochemical parameter analyses. AChE activity and ACh concentrations were measured using assay kits (Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute, China), following manufacturer's instructions, and total protein levels were determined using Bradford assay method (Bradford, 1976; Harlow and Lane, 2006) .
body_text.section: Ache activity and ACh concentration measurement

body_text.text: Total RNA extractions of larval samples followed a spin column adsorption method previously conducted (Mu et al., 2015a) . Detailed methods regarding total RNA isolation, purification, quantification, detection of the purity, first-strand cDNA synthesis, and quantitative real-time PCR are provided in our previous studies (Mu et al., 2015b) . The stability of the housekeeping gene, β-actin, in zebrafish larvae after boscalid exposure is further described in the Supplementary Material. A list of primers used for qPCR are provided in Table S1 .

Water samples were taken at 0 and 1 dpe for embryonic (5 mL) and adult exposures (10 mL). The water sample pretreatment and detection methods were conducted as previously described (Qian et al., 2018) . Additional details regarding sample extraction is provided in the Supplementary Material section.

The instrumental quality control (QC) for the analysis of boscalid using high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) (Agilent Technologies, USA) was estimated using matrix-dependent LOD (limit of detection), LOQ (limit of quantification) and instrumental repeatability. LOD and LOQ were defined as signal to noise ratio (S/N) of 3 and 10, respectively. Extraction recoveries and relative standard deviation (RSD) were obtained from three spiked concentration levels (0.01, 0.1 and 1.0 mg/L) in reconstituted water.

SPSS 17.0 software (SPSS, USA) was used for all statistical analyses. A Shapiro-Wilk's test and Levene's test were used to verify normality and homogeneity of variances of the data. Logarithmic transformation was performed in partial data of locomotor activity, distance moved and predation ability to meet the requirement for homogeneity of variance. An independent sample T-test or a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA), followed by a Dunnett's post hoc test, was conducted to assess mean differences between control treatments and boscalid-exposed groups. The total distance moved per min intervals was displayed as mean ± standard error of mean (SEM) and all other assessments are presented as mean ± standard deviation (SD). A p < 0.05 was used to indicate statistical difference between groups.

The LOD of boscalid was 0.028 mg/L and the LOQ was 0.094 mg/L in reconstituted water. The recoveries of all three spiked concentration levels (0.01, 0.1 and 1.0 mg/L) in reconstituted water ranged from 98.5% to 111.9% with the RSD ranging from 2.6% to 6.2%.

Deviations between the actual exposure concentrations of boscalid in reconstituted water and nominal concentrations were within ± 20% (Table S2) . Therefore, the nominal concentrations of boscalid were used to report the actual exposure concentrations of boscalid.

The locomotor indicators of larval zebrafish in all boscalid-treated groups showed a general decreased tendency in a time-and concentration-dependent manner (Fig. 1A-D ). Larvae exposed to 0.6 and 1.2 mg/ L for 7 and 8 d had a significant inhibition (p < 0.01) in all locomotor indicators assessed, relative to control treatments. Furthermore, larvae had significantly suppressed relative average velocity, acceleration and distance moved following exposure to 0.3 mg/L boscalid for 8 d. Similarly, the results of dark photokinesis assay showed that following an exposure to 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L boscalid induced hypoactivity in larvae at 8 dpe ( Fig. 1E-H ), which was characterized by a significant decrease in total distance moved in both trial 1 and 2 ( Fig. 1G and H) .

In addition, there was a significant inhibition of phototactic behavior in 5 and 8 dpe larvae following exposure to 1.2 mg/L boscalid ( Fig. S2) , with the percentage of larvae migrating from the dark chamber to the Fig. 1 . The behavioral response of larval zebrafish after exposure to boscalid (0, 0.3, 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L) (n = 3). Compared with the control group, the locomotor activity of larvae from the 5th to 8th days of exposure, including relative average velocity (A), relative average acceleration (B) relative active time (C) and relative distance moved (D). Total distance moved of larvae over the 50 min in a dark photokinesis behavioral assay. Total distance moved per min intervals (E and F) (data was shown as mean ± SEM) and per dark-light period (G and H) (data was shown as mean ± SD) after 8-d exposure in trial 1 and 2, respectively. (*p < 0.05; **p < 0.01).

illuminated chamber were significantly decreased by 70% and 52%, respectively. However, no significant differences were observed in the 0.3 and 0.6 mg/L treatment groups when compared to controls. Adult zebrafish exposed to 1.0 mg/L of boscalid for 21 d had a significantly inhibited average velocity ( Fig. 2A) and acceleration (Fig. 2B ), but a significantly increased active time (Fig. 2C ) and distance moved ( Fig. 2D ; p < 0.05). In addition, predation trajectories of adult zebrafish in all boscalid treatment groups were affected ( Fig. 2E) , showing a preference for swimming around the beaker wall. The predation ability of zebrafish to D. magna was significantly altered (p < 0.01) following a 0.1 and 1.0 mg/L treatment (Table 1) , which resulted in a prolonged predation time and reduced predation rate. The predation rate of adult zebrafish was reduced by 30% and 100% following exposure to 0.1 and 1.0 mg/L boscalid, respectively. However, no significant changes were observed in the predation time and predation rate of adult zebrafish following 0.01 mg/L treatment.

RNA-Seq analysis revealed that boscalid exposure induced significant alterations in the global gene transcription profiles in zebrafish larvae. The control and boscalid-treatment groups were well separated from each other and strongly clustered, with the total amount of variation explained from PC1 and PC2 being 43.38% and 17.46%, respectively, as determined from a principal component analysis (PCA) score plot (Fig. S3A) . A total of 2253 DEGs, including 884 significantly upregulated and 1369 significantly downregulated DEGs, were found in boscalid-exposed zebrafish larvae (Fig. S3B) . Additionally, a heatmap dendrogram further depicts the expression of DEGs in zebrafish larvae between the control and boscalid treatment (Fig. S4 ) using z-score The effects of boscalid on zebrafish larvae were further demonstrated using GO and KEGG pathway analysis. Based on these DEGs, we identified several enriched terms from the different GO categories, which were comprised of 2766 BP (biological process), 716 MF (molecular function), and 417 CC (cellular component), using the R package cluster Profiler. Among them, biological processes were significantly enriched, with the top processes involved in metabolism, genetic information processing, environmental information processing, cellular processes, and organismal systems. Among the top thirty significantly enrich GO terms, (p-value < 0.05), the most affected biological processes were associated with the ribonucleotide biosynthetic process, small molecule biosynthetic process, ribose phosphate biosynthetic process and sensory perception of light stimulus (Table S3 ; Fig. 3A) . Additionally, it was noted that in the GO domains of biological processes, the downregulated DEGs were significantly associated with visual perception, sensory perception of light stimulus, and nervous system processes (Table S4) .

The most significant KEGG pathways affected were associated with metabolism (carbohydrate metabolism, lipid metabolism, amino acid metabolism, and nucleotide metabolism) and organismal systems, including the sensory system (phototransduction) and endocrine system (PPAR signaling pathway) (Table S5 ; Fig. 3B ). Phototransduction was the most significantly enriched pathway in the KEGG pathway based on the number of downregulated DEGs (Table S6) .

RT-PCR was used to validate the expression of 14 genes involved in top predicted pathways determined through RNA-Seq analysis (Fig. S5) . The expression levels of 12 of the 14 genes examined were similar to the results of RNA-Seq. However, two genes (gcnt and kitb), had conflicting relationships when compared with RNA-Seq data.

A proper lamination of retinal layers was observed in the eyes of 4 ( Fig. 4C ) and 8 dpe (Fig. 4E ) control larvae. No obvious changes were observed in the retina of larvae exposed to 1.2 mg/L for 4 d (Fig. 4D ). However, a disordered arrangement, increased intercellular space and partial cell clusters (Fig. 4F) in the INL was observed in 8 dpe larvae exposed to 1.2 mg/L boscalid.
body_text.section: Histopathological changes in the eye and brain

body_text.text: In addition, the round cell nucleus in the larval brain was compactly arranged at 4 ( Fig. 5A ) and 8 dpe (Fig. 5C ) in the control treatment group. However, a significant, 23% and 44%, reduction in the relative round cell nucleus in the brain of 4 (Fig. 5B and E1 ) and d ( Fig. 5D and E2) larvae exposed to 1.2 mg/L boscalid was observed, in relation to the control group.
body_text.section: Histopathological changes in the eye and brain

body_text.text: The relative diameters of the adult zebrafish eyeball and cornea were significantly decreased in the 0.1 (Fig. S6C and E ) and 1.0 mg/L ( Fig. S6D and E ) treatment groups following a 21-d exposure. The ratio of cornea/eyeball diameter was also reduced in the 1.0 mg/L treatment group (Fig. S6F) . HE stained sections indicated that the relative average thickness of the PL in the retina showed a declining trend in all boscalidexposed groups (Fig. 6B-D) , where the PL was significantly decreased by 21% and 39% in the 0.1 and 1.0 mg/L (Fig. 6M ) boscalid groups, respectively (p < 0.05).
body_text.section: Histopathological changes in the eye and brain

body_text.text: There was a significant, 28%, decrease in the relative density of GrCs in the brain of zebrafish exposed to 1.0 mg/L boscalid ( Fig. 6H and N) . Moreover, vasodilation was observed in the 0.01 (Fig. 6I) , 0.1 (Fig. 6J) , and 1.0 mg/L (Fig. 6K ) treatment groups, with neuronophagia noted in the cerebellar molecular layer in 1.0 mg/L (Fig. 6L ) treatment group.
body_text.section: Histopathological changes in the eye and brain

body_text.text: The AChE activity in larvae exposed to 0.3 mg/L boscalid was not significantly different from controls at 4 dpe (Fig. 7A) , though significantly decreased by 16% and 23% in the 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L groups (p < 0.05). Similarly, a significant decrease in AChE activity was seen in 8 dpe larvae exposed to 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L boscalid. The decreased AChE activity resulted in the accumulation of Ach, with a significant increase in ACh concentration in larvae exposed to 1.2 mg/L boscalid at 4 and 8 dpe (p < 0.05; Fig. 7B ), with a 21% and 71% increase, respectively..

A significant decrease in the mRNA expression of mbp was found in 4 dpe larvae exposed to 1.2 mg/L boscalid (Fig. 7C ) and in all boscalid treatment groups by 8 dpe (Fig. 7D) . Boscalid significantly downregulated syn2a mRNA expression in the 1.2 mg/L group at 4 dpe, and induced 23%, 44% and 89% reductions in syn2a expression in 8 dpe larvae following a 0.3, 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L boscalid exposure. No significant differences (p > 0.05) in gfap mRNA expression were observed by 4 or 8 dpe, regardless of exposure treatment. The mRNA expression of α1tubulin remained stable at 4 dpe in all treatment groups, but a significant increase was observed in 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L treatment groups at 8 dpe. The mRNA expression of gap43 was significantly up-regulated in 4 dpe larvae exposed to 0.6 mg/L boscalid, as well as in 8 dpe larvae exposed to 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L boscalid.

The expression profiles of genes (opn1sw1, opn1mw1, opn1lw2, opn4xb, opn4.1, rho, and rhol) related to eye development and visual function at 4 and 8 dpe is shown in Fig. 7E and F. Larvae exposed to 0.3 mg/L boscalid had a significantly increased mRNA expression of opn1sw1, opn1mw1, opn4.1 and rho at 4 dpe and opn1sw1, opn1lw2, opn4xb and rho mRNA expression at 8 dpe. Interestingly, there was a significant downregulation of all tested genes in 4 dpe larvae exposed to 1.2 mg/L boscalid, in addition to 8 dpe larvae exposed to 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L (except for opn1sw1 in the 0.6 mg/L group). Notably, compared with the controls, the expression of rho and rhol was reduced by 92% and 81% following exposure to 1.2 mg/L for 8 d, respectively. All tested genes (except for opn4xb) were not differentially affected by 0.6 mg/L boscalid at 4 dpe.

In this study, embryonic and adult zebrafish were utilized to evaluate the neurobehavioral and visually-mediated effects of boscalid and better characterize molecular-level changes to behavioral-level response. Behavioral responses (swimming, phototaxis, and predation), histopathology, transcriptomics, and the related biochemical parameters and gene expression profiles of zebrafish following exposure to environmentally relevant concentrations of boscalid (i.e., 0.01 mg/L) were evaluated. Our findings demonstrated that boscalid significantly inhibited the locomotor ability and phototactic response of larvae after 8 d of exposure (0.3-1.2 mg/L), and altered the locomotor activity, predation trajectories and ability in adults after 21 d of exposure (0.01-1.0 mg/L). Similarly, Wang et al. (2020) reported that boscalid at higher concentrations (5, 15 and 25 mg/L) reduced the locomotor activity of zebrafish embryos and larvae after an acute exposure (Wang et al., 2020) . As a rapid development plays vital roles in a predator avoidance response due to swimming ability (Fisher et al., 2010) , a decline in the average velocity and acceleration of larvae following boscalid exposure may increase environmental risks to fish. Significant inhibitions in visually-mediated behavioral responses (phototactic response of larvae and predation of adults) in our study may exacerbate this adverse effect. Exposure to the agricultural pesticide, chlorpyrifos, impaired visual lateralization in a larval coral reef fish, which may further increase larval mortality (Besson et al., 2017) . Visual behavior has been widely used to characterize the effects of chemicals on visual capabilities in zebrafish and medaka (Oryzias latipes) (Mueller and Neuhauss, 2010; Stephenson et al., 2012; Magnuson et al., 2020) . In addition, boscalid significantly affected the predation trajectories of adult zebrafish, which showed a thigmotactic response, a preference for swimming around the beaker wall, which has been previously characterized in zebrafish (Maximino et al., 2010; Schnorr et al., 2012) . Thigmotaxis, considered as a validated index of anxiety, was significantly weakened by anxiolytic drugs and significantly enhanced by anxiogenic drugs in zebrafish. Previous studies have reported that an increased distance moved is considered to be one of the manifestations of anxiety (Collier et al., 2017) . Thigmotaxic behavior and increased distance moved, as determined in our study, further suggests that exposure to boscalid may cause anxiety in adult zebrafish.

Many behaviors rely on visual function in fish (Shi et al., 2019) . Disorders that impair visually-mediated behaviors may be due to alterations in visual structure and function (Demb and Singer, 2015; Stengel et al., 2018) . The vertebrate eye consists of optical components such as Fig. 7 . The AChE activity, ACh concentrations and the expression of genes involved in nervous system development in larvae after exposure to 0, 0.3, 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L boscalid for 4 and 8 d (n = 3). A: AChE activity at 4 and 8 dpe; B: ACh concentrations at 4 and 8 dpe; C and D: Expression of genes related to neurodevelopment and transmission at 4 dpe and 8 dpe, respectively. E and F: Expression of genes related to eye development and visual function at 4 dpe and 8 dpe, respectively. (*p < 0.05; **p < 0.01).

the cornea, lens, and humor that are involved in transmitting and focusing light energy on the retina (Sivak, 1990) . The retina, an extension of the central nervous system (CNS), consists of neurons and glia (Ramasamy et al., 2019) . The retina plays vital roles in converting this visual information into electrical signals and transmitting them to the brain, where the information is interpreted. The INL of the retina is made up of a number of closely packed cells, some of which are specialized sensory neurons used for the transmission of light (Masland, 2012) . Photoreceptor cells in the PL, composed of rods, cones, and intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells (RGCs), are neuroepithelial cells that are associated with visual phototransduction (Malicki et al., 2011; Remington, 2012) . Therefore, alterations to the INL and PL in the retina in zebrafish might affect sensory transmission and visual phototransduction, which may eventually impair proper visual function and result in a reduced ability to capture prey. Additionally, the cornea allows light to enter the eye and is responsible for providing most of the focusing power for the eye (Winkler et al., 2015) . Decreased diameters of the eyeball, cornea, and the ratio of the cornea/eyeball diameter were observed following a 0.1 and 1.0 mg/L boscalid treatment in our study, which suggested that boscalid may lead to microphthalmia in adult zebrafish and subsequently impair proper visual function (Kashyap et al., 2007; Mishra and Devi, 2014) . There is increasing evidence that the eyes may be sensitive targets to certain classes of pesticides (Soares et al., 2016; Besson et al., 2017) . Previous studies have found that Lufenuron promoted damage in the retina of fish Colossoma macropomum and chlorpyrifos induced apoptosis in the superficial zone of the optic tectum and resulted in microphthalmia in the fresh water teleost Channa punctatus (Mishra and Devi, 2014) .

According to our RNA-Seq results, sensory perception of light stimulus and visual perception were among the most significantly affected biological processes in zebrafish larvae following boscalid treatment, which are associated with visual phototransduction. Visual phototransduction is the sensory transduction of the visual system that occurs on the retina, involving the conversion of light into electrical signals in photoreceptor cells (Remington, 2012) . Opsins (cone opsins and rhodopsin) are known as light-sensitive proteins in visual pigments in vertebrates that are synthesized by photoreceptors (Lamb, 2013) . Opsin genes usually encode G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) that mediate phototransduction (Terakita, 2005) . The mRNA expression of cone opsin genes (opn1sw1, opn1mw1, opn1lw1) and rhodopsin genes (rho and rhol) were significantly decreased in larval zebrafish exposed to 0.6 and 1.2 mg/L boscalid for 8 d, which may interfere with synthesis of GPCRs and even phototransduction of fish. Additionally, melanopsin genes (such as opn4.1 and opn4xb) that are additionally expressed in photoreceptors and interneurons throughout the INL, and involved in signaling light information to RGCs (Matos-Cruz et al., 2011; Sousa et al., 2017) , were also significantly downregulated following exposure to boscalid, which may reduce melanopsin synthesis and affect visual phototransduction in larval zebrafish. As zebrafish predominately use their sense of sight to hunt for food and avoid predators (Fleisch and Neuhauss, 2006) , the effects of boscalid on the visual system may interfere with proper predatory response behavior, which was altered in our study.

Due to the large number of neurocytes in the brain, brain damage is usually related to an occurrence of neurotoxicity (Carpentier et al., 2001) . GrCs accounts for half of the neurons in the brain and provides necessary contextual information for motor learning in Purkinje cells (Giovannucci et al., 2017) . GrCs encode multiple sensorimotor signals in the cerebellar input layer according to theories of cerebellar function (Knogler et al., 2017) . Our study showed that boscalid affected the brain development of larvae and induced brain injuries in adults, which was characterized by decreased relative round cell nucleus in the larval brain and in the density of GrCs in adults. This suggests that boscalid induced neurotoxicity and impaired the ability to capture sensorimotor signals in zebrafish.

Accordingly, RNA-Seq results indicated that boscalid affected nervous system processes in larvae. Nervous system development is essential for individual development, and the nervous system is susceptible to exogenous pollutants, such as heavy metals and organochlorine pollutants (Alexander et al., 2006; He et al., 2013) . Increasing evidence suggests that behavioral responses can reflect the neurotoxicity caused by environmental pollutants to organisms in a macroscopic sense (Duffard, 1996) . Chen et al., (2012) found that deficits in motor behavior that were caused by polybrominated diphenyl ethers (PBDEs) may be associated with the altered patterns of neuronal connectivity (Chen et al., 2012) . We speculate that the alterations in motor and visual behaviors of zebrafish by boscalid could be related to neurodevelopment and transmission. Neurotransmitters play key roles in the development of the nervous system (Mattson, 1988) . Studies have shown that imbalances in neurotransmitter concentrations can cause a variety of neurological disorders. ACh, a neurotransmitter that plays vital functions in the CNS, is released into the synaptic cleft upon nerve stimulation (Bengel et al., 2010) . ACh was also found as a retinal neurotransmitter in vertebrates (Martins and Pearson, 2008) . AChE is the rate-limiting enzyme in ACh metabolism, making it crucial for cholinergic neurotransmission, and has been a biomarker for toxicity assessment of organophosphate pesticides (Liu and Lin, 2006; Pimsen et al., 2014; Lu et al., 2018) . AChE is critical for the neurodevelopment of zebrafish embryos, and it is thought to be a sensitive endpoint for assessing developmental delays in the absence of malformations (Teixidó et al., 2013) . Accordingly, boscalid significantly decreased AChE activity in zebrafish following an exposure to 1.2 mg/L and in turn induced an increase in ACh concentration, which may lead to neurodevelopmental delay and abnormal neurotransmission in zebrafish.

The mRNA expression of key genes (mbp, α1-tubulin, gap43 and syn2a) involved in neurodevelopment and transmission were also significantly altered in larvae following boscalid treatment in our study (Fan et al., 2010; Shi et al., 2018) , which further supports that boscalid is neurotoxic to zebrafish. Myelin basic protein (MBP), which is widely expressed in the myelin membrane in the CNS, is involved in the formation and stabilization of the myelin membrane (Zecević et al., 1998) . A significant reduction in the mRNA expression of mbp in larvae following boscalid exposure might cause a lack of myelination and damage to neuronal functions (Brosamle and Halpern, 2002) . Tubulin alpha 1 (α1-Tubulin) is the major constituent of the microtubules and plays important roles in the development of the microtubule cytoskeleton and the regeneration of axons and dendrites (Hieber et al., 1998) .

The significant upregulation of α1-tubulin in larvae following boscalid treatment might be a negative feedback regulation to reduce the associated brain injury, though further study is needed to assess this relationship. Growth associated protein-43 (GAP43) is a neuron-specific protein involved in extracellular growth and triggering neuronal regeneration, that is associated with nerve growth (Udvadia, 2008) . The expression of gap43 in larvae showed a significantly increased trend following a prolonged exposure to boscalid, which may be caused by nerve injury, thereby affecting neurite formation, regeneration and plasticity (Mearow et al., 1994; Youn et al., 1998) . Synapsins are mainly involved in the exocytosis of synaptic vesicles, synaptogenesis and neurotransmitter release (Cesca et al., 2010) . Synapsin IIa, one isoform of synapsins, plays important roles in presynaptic nerve terminals (Siow et al., 1992) . Molinaro et al. (2015) reported that disruptions in the expression of synapsin IIa interferes with synaptic function, resulting in the imbalance of neurotransmitters and subsequent pathogenesis of schizophrenia (Molinaro et al., 2015) . Significant decrease in the mRNA expression of syn2a in larvae following boscalid treatment may affect the release and functions of ACh, leading to its accumulation in the body. Similarly, zebrafish larvae exposed to atrazine and its main metabolites induced a significant downregulation of syn2a, which affected synaptogenesis and the regulation of proper neurotransmitter release (Liu et al., 2016; Gu et al., 2019) .

In summary, our results demonstrated that boscalid affected cell differentiation in the eyes of zebrafish and induced brain injury, which may weaken the ability to capture surrounding visual information and sensorimotor signals, thereby significantly inhibiting locomotor activity and phototactic responses of larvae, as well as predation ability in adults. The expression of genes involved in neurodevelopment, transmission, eye development, and visual function, in conjunction with transcriptomics analysis, provides further evidence that the effects of boscalid on visual and nervous systems may be the main cause of neurobehavioral disorders in zebrafish. Additionally, taking into consideration that boscalid affected the predation trajectory and induced vasodilation in the brains of adult zebrafish following exposure to concentrations of boscalid frequently detected in surface waters (i.e., 0.036 mg/L) (Smalling and Orlando, 2011) , more attention should be placed on the potential risks of boscalid to aquatic organisms. These findings provide more insights into understanding the mechanism of boscalid-induced effects to proper neurobehavioral responses in zebrafish.

FIGREF0.text: The behavioral response of adult zebrafish after exposure to 0, 0.01, 0.1 and 1.0 mg/L boscalid (n = 3). A: Relative average velocity; B: Relative average acceleration; C: Relative active time; D: relative distance moved; E: Predation trajectories. (*p < 0.05; **p < 0.01).

FIGREF1.text: GO enrichment analysis (A) and KEGG enrichment analysis (B) of DEGs in the 1.2 mg/L boscalid-treated group. normalization and hierarchical clustering, which shows strong clades between treatment groups.

FIGREF2.text: Hematoxylin-eosin (HE) stained sections of eye in zebrafish larvae exposed to 0 and 1.2 mg/L boscalid at 4 and 8 dpe (100×). A: Longitudinal cut diagram; B: The main structure of eye, RPE, PL, ONL, INL, IPL, GCL, and lens; C: Control at 4 dpe; D: 1.2 mg/L at 4 dpe; E: Control at 8 dpe; F: 1.2 mg/L at 8 dpe; The black arrows indicate increased intercellular space and the yellow arrows indicate partial cell clusters. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

FIGREF3.text: HE stained sections of brain in zebrafish larvae exposed to 0 and 1.2 mg/L boscalid at 4 and 8 dpe (100×). A: Control at 4 dpe; B: 1.2 mg/L at 4 dpe; C: Control at 8 dpe; D: 1.2 mg/L at 8 dpe. The yellow asterisks in A-D indicate round cell nucleus of brain. E1 and E2: Relative round cell nucleus of brain at 4 and 8 dpe (n = 3). (*p < 0.05; **p < 0.01). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

FIGREF4.text: HE stained sections of eye and brain of adult zebrafish exposed to 0, 0.01, 0.1 and 1.0 mg/L boscalid for 21 d. The eye sections of adult zebrafish (200×). A: Control; B: 0.01 mg/L; C: 0.1 mg/L; D: 1.0 mg/L. The white dotted lines indicate the thickness of the PL. The brain sections of adult zebrafish (200×). E: Control; F/I: 0.01 mg/L; G/J: 0.1 mg/L; H/K/L: 1.0 mg/L. The yellow arrows indicate the GrCs of zebrafish. Black arrows indicate vasodilation, and the yellow dotted circle indicates neuronophagia in the cerebellar molecular layer. M represents relative thickness of the PL and N represents density of GrCs (n = 3). (*p < 0.05; **p < 0.01). (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)
